{"step_by_step_thinking": "The 'July effect' refers to the phenomenon of adverse impacts on patient care arising from the changeover in medical staff that takes place during this month at academic medical centres in North America. Document [0] states that there is an absence of a July effect in patients undergoing major cancer surgery. Document [1] also does not support evidence of a 'July effect' in patients undergoing head and neck cancer surgery. Document [2] found no difference in morbidity or mortality after Whipple procedures performed in July compared to the remainder of the academic year. Document [3] found higher rates of in-hospital mortality and intraoperative complications in July, but this was for surgery for metastatic spinal disease, not cancer surgery. Document [4] found no worse outcomes for women undergoing hysterectomy surgery at academic hospitals during July through September. Document [8] found no July effect for plastic surgery procedures. Document [9] found that operative mortality rates were no higher in July than in other months combined for all procedures. Document [10] found no evidence of a July effect in patients undergoing primary total shoulder arthroplasty. Document [21] found no increase in mortality or morbidity during the early academic period. Document [22] found no association of an interaction term for academic quarter and resident involvement with 'serious adverse events'. Document [26] found no correlation between time of year and operative morbidity or mortality. Document [29] found that day of surgery admission did not adversely affect a wide range of outcomes for patients having a resection for colorectal cancer.", "answer_choice": "B"}
